<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: import java.io.*;
import java.util.*;

class dothis {
  public static void main (String [] args) throws IOException {
    BufferedReader f = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("ride.in"));
    PrintWriter out = new PrintWriter(new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("ride.out")));
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(f.readLine());
    String s1 = "";
    String s2 = "";
    if (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
      s1 = st.nextToken();
    }
    if (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
      s2 = st.nextToken();
    }
    char[] arr = new char[6];
    if (find(s1, arr, 1) == find(s2, arr, 1)) {
      out.print("one");
    } else {
      out.println("two");
    }
    out.close();
  }
  
  public static int find(String s, char[] arr, int index) {
    // implementation of find method
    return 0;
  }
}
<<<explanation>>>: The exception "NoSuchElementException" is thrown when there are no more tokens to be read from the StringTokenizer. In your code, you are assuming that there will always be two tokens available, but this may not be the case. To avoid this exception, you can use the hasMoreTokens() method to check if there are more tokens available before calling nextToken(). In the modified code, I have added these checks before assigning values to s1 and s2. This way, if there are no more tokens available, the variables will remain empty strings.
